conclusion: Determine the instantaneous value of the induced current and the average value of the induced EMF.
The induced EMF in a rotating loop in a magnetic field is given by the formula: \( \mathcal{E} = B S \omega \sin(\theta) \).
Calculate the instantaneous EMF using \( \theta = 60^\circ \) which is \( \frac{\pi}{3} \) radians: \( \mathcal{E} = B S \omega \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \).
The induced current \( I \) is given by Ohm's law: \( I = \frac{\mathcal{E}}{R} \).
Calculate the instantaneous induced current: \( I = \frac{B S \omega \sqrt{3}}{2R} \).
The average induced EMF over a time interval can be found by integrating the instantaneous EMF over that interval and dividing by the time interval.
Calculate the time interval \( \Delta t \) for a rotation of 60°: \( \Delta t = \frac{\pi}{3\omega} \).
Calculate the average EMF: \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{avg}} = \frac{3\omega B S}{2\pi} \).
The instantaneous induced current when the wire frame rotates through an angle of 60° is \( \frac{B S \omega \sqrt{3}}{2R} \).
The average value of the induced EMF during this process is \( \frac{3\omega B S}{2\pi} \).
